awd_titl_txt: The SRCOS Summer Research Conference in Statistics and Biostatistics
awd_abstract_narration:
The investigator and his colleagues will organize and conduct a Summer Research Conference (SRC) in statistics and biostatistics at Virginia Beach Resort Hotel and Conference Center in Virginia Beach, Virginia on June 3-6, 2018.  The 2018 SRC will be the 54th anniversary of that conference.  The SRC is an annual conference sponsored by the Southern Regional Council on Statistics (SRCOS).  Its purpose is to encourage the interchange and mutual understanding of current research ideas in statistics and biostatistics, and to give motivation and direction to further research progress.  The project will focus on young researchers, placing them in close proximity to leaders in the field for person-to-person interactions in a manner not possible at most other meetings.  Speakers will present formal research talks with adequate time allowed for clarification, amplification, and further informal discussions in small groups. Under the travel support provided by this award students will attend and present their research in posters to be reviewed by more experienced researchers. 

The Southern Regional Council on Statistics is a consortium of statistics and biostatistics programs in the South, stretching as far west as Texas and as far north as Maryland.  It currently has member programs at 45 universities in 16 states in the region.  This project will fund student participation in the 2018 Summer Research Conference (SRC) sponsored by SRCOS.  The meeting is particularly valuable for students and faculty from smaller regional schools at drivable distances, affording them the opportunity to participate and interact closely with internationally-known leaders in the field without the cost of travel to distant national or international venues.  It will strengthen the research of the statistics and biostatistics community as a whole, and particularly in the relatively underdeveloped southern region.  For all details, go to the conference link at http://odu.edu/math/srcos/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Summer Research Conference (SRC) is an annual research conference sponsored by the Southern Regional Council on Statistics (SRCOS). Since the inception of the SRC, the purposes of the conference are to encourage the interchange and mutual understanding of research ideas in statistics and biostatistics, and to give motivation and direction to further research progress, particularly for young researchers, in a manner not ordinarily possible at other meetings. The meeting is particularly valuable for graduate students, isolated statisticians, and faculty from smaller regional schools in the Southern Region. Each year, the location of the conference is chosen to be at a drivable distance for researchers in the Southern Region, thus affording them the opportunity to participate and interact closely with internationally-known leaders in the field without the cost of travel to distant venues. Speakers present formal research talks with adequate time allowed for clarification, amplification, and further informal discussions in small groups. As such, speakers, session chairs, and discussants make themselves accessible for informal discussions of their research as well as formal presentations.

On the second day of the conference, the NSF/R.L. Anderson Student Poster Session for graduate students is featured. An overwhelming majority of faculty and senior researchers stay and view the student posters. The Student Poster Session includes a competition, with student posters judged by leaders in the field. The Student Poster Session provides an excellent opportunity for the young scholars to gain experience and obtain feedback. Awards in honor of SRCOS founders are presented that evening at the conference banquet. A separate poster session for young faculty and isolated statisticians allows them a means of participation.

The 54th Annual Summer Research Conference (SRC) was held June 3rd - June 6th, 2018 in Virginia Beach, Virginia at the Virginia Beach Resort Hotel and Conference Center. It was co-organized by the Southern Regional Council on Statistics (SRCOS) and the University of Kentucky and hosted by Old Dominion University. Ninety-nine scholars from institutions across the country (Michigan to Florida, the Carolinas to California) participated. The website for the meeting is https://www.odu.edu/math/srcos, and it contains program details, abstracts, and photos of conference activities.  

Thanks to NSF support for students, limited SRCOS funds from registrations and membership fees could be used to provide support for two internationally-renowned keynote speakers: Philip Ernst of Rice University and Michael Kosorok of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Discussants for these keynote speakers were Frederi Veins of Michigan State University and Dr. Norou Diawara of Old Dominion University, respectively.  Dr. Susmita Data of the University of Florida and Rudy Guerra of Rice University organized five additional stimulating invited oral sessions, each featuring one senior and two additional outstanding faculty speakers.  The after dinner speaker, Dr. Mike Kutner totally surprised Dr. Elizabeth Slate recognizing her for “Outstanding Leadership” for her dedication as President-elect and President from 2014 to 2017.  In addition, Dr. Edward Boone received the Paul Minton Achievement Award.

The NSF/R.L. Anderson Student Poster Session featured poster presentations from 30 graduate students, representing 15 graduate programs across the Southern Region.  Travel awards were provided by funding from the National Science Foundation, with additional support from the American Statistical Association (ASA) and SRCOS. These awards enabled students, in many cases representing programs with limited travel budgets, to experience a significant scientific conference firsthand. They interacted closely with leading researchers in the field in a manner that is not possible at larger national or international meetings (which would also be prohibitively expensive for many of these students to attend). The M. Clinton Miller award for Best Student Poster went to Jieun Park from Auburn University. The R. L. Anderson poster award went to both Shubhadeep Chakraborty from Texas A&M University.

The winner of the 2018 fifth annual Kutner/ASA best poster award for a junior faculty member was Roland Matsouaka from Duke University and Katherine Thompson from the University of Kentucky.  There were 15 faculty contributions.   In addition to a generous contribution from Mike Kutner, funds from ASA, SRCOS, Statistical and Applied Mathematical Sciences Institute (SAMSI), and the National Institute of Statistical Sciences (NISS) Affiliates Fund helped defray the cost of attendance for these faculty participants.  

The co-chairs of the scientific program were Dr. Susmita Data of the University of Florida and Rudy Guerra of Rice University, together with SRCOS officers. The faculty and student poster sessions were coordinated by Ed Boone and Qin Wang, respectively, both from Virginia Commonwealth University. Norou Diawara from Old Dominion University coordinated all local arrangements in Virginia Beach, and Arny Stromberg from the University of Kentucky provided additional administrative support.
